title: Davidvictorson
author: Davidvictorson
content: Our world is filled with so many myths, superstitions, and legends of one form or another. And gambling is no exception.Â  So many people hold fast to them because they believe in their potency. For example, in my culture, though it is not related to gambling, one of the superstitions I find quite funny is that, whistling or playing any sort of wind instrument after 9pm is forbidden because it is believed to attract evil spirits. I have never played cards at a casino before but as a kid growing up, I played a lot of card games with family and friends. I was shocked to find out that there are myths, superstitions, and legends about playing cards. Below I have compiled some of popular myths, superstitions and legends about playing cards. After reading it, I would like to know what you have heard about playing cards.1. Walk three times around the playing table for good luckQuoteSometimes luck is just not on your side when playing a card game which can result in a losing streak. It is believed that your luck can change when you walk around the table three times before continuing the game.2. It is bad to sing, whistle, or drop cards while playingQuoteThis belief largely comes from Chinese superstition. Singing, whistling, or dropping cards when playing is considered disrespectful and a sign of rudeness.3. Avoid crossing your legs when playingQuoteOne of the older myths when playing cards is the belief that players should not cross their legs when playing. It is said that doing so would destroy any chances of winning a game.4. Donâ€™t buy a deck for yourselfQuoteThis belief is rooted in using cards for a tarot reading. It is considered bad luck to buy it for yourself. Additionally, you canâ€™t use the same deck for both tarot reading and playing cards.5. 52 is a lucky numberQuoteAccording to Asian tradition, 52 is a lucky number in card games. In numerology, the number means good fortune and positive change. The most common belief, however, is that the 52 cards are meant to represent the 52 weeks that pass in a year. Additionally, the four card suits represent the four seasons and the 13 cards within it represent the 13 weeks within each season.6. Getting a dark hand has a dark meaningQuoteIt is commonly believed that when you have a hand consisting of an all-black card suit, that means that someone will die.7. The Joker and December 31QuoteWhile December 31st is popularly celebrated for the coming of New Year, it is also known as the Jokerâ€™s birthday. In the olden days, it was considered a day for merriment. On this day, court jesters can showcase their best performance and impersonate royalties such as the King.8. Cards were used to send secret maps by POWs during WWIIQuoteThe most fascinating legend about playing cards comes during the time of World War II. Allied Prisoners of War held across Germany and occupied Europe were allowed to receive packages from the Red Cross thanks to the Geneva Convention. Seeing this as an opportunity, the Allies smuggled several disguised items to POWs to avoid detection from the enemy captors. With the help of the United States Playing Card Company (USPCC) and their brand, Bicycle, they produced a deck of cards that had a hidden map within it. The map hidden on the card was revealed once submerged in water and soft enough to peel off the outer layers. Each card contained a piece of the map and was assembled once all the pieces were revealed. The map, once assembled, contained valuable information within it, including escape route directions, to help POWs to escape and reach safety. These cards were distributed during Christmas, as part of Red Crossâ€™ Christmas parcels. 32 POWs managed to escape captivity with help from the map. This unique collaboration between the Allied Intelligence and USPCC was commemorated by the reproduction of the decks. 9. The Left Hand CurseQuoteWhen sitting at the poker table or playing any other card or table game, itâ€™s believed (according to Chinese superstition) that using the left hand is rude and doing so will see the player being punished by the gods. As such, all players must use their right hand (even left-handed players).10. Striking a needle into fabric worn by a particular person would help them win at cardsQuoteIn old fables and tales, it is believed that striking a pin or a needle into the fabric (clothing) of the person you wish would win the card game would cause them to win. It could only work if the person didnâ€™t see you sticking the needle into their clothing.11. Card playing on Friday before six is a big NO!QuoteA typical old superstition says that playing cards on Friday before 6 pm is considered to be a bad omen. Waiting until after 6 pm was the norm.12. You shouldnâ€™t play cards after midnightQuotePlaying card games after midnight, especially at 3 am, is considered bad luck. Some legends say that playing cards at 3 am could leave you open to demons.13. You need mathematics skills to play BlackjackQuotePeople believed that Blackjack required considerable mathematical skills, but thatâ€™s not true! To be able to play the game, you simply have to learn the rules and practice.14. The kings on the cards are depictions of real kingsQuoteSome people believe that the four Kings of a playing card deck represent four real-life kings through history: Charlemagne, David, Caesar and Alexander. There was a time in the history of cards when French card designs were the most commonly used throughout Europe and French card designers liked to assign identities to the royals pictured on their cards.15. Players of the Ander Bahar card game have a 50% chance of winningQuoteAnder Bahar, a card game that originated in India, and they say that players have a 50-50 chance of winning.What myths, superstitions, and legends have you heard about playing cards.Sources:https://livecasino.io/blog/casino-tips/the-joker-playing-cardhttps://giftsforcardplayers.com/card-games-myths-and-superstitions-you-want-to-know/http://greatbridgelinks.com/myths-about-cards/https://www.gamesver.com/card-games-superstitions-myths-legends-about-playing-cards/

comments.body: from this list i just heard that to be a winner at card games you have to be good at math, in my country when we played cards if someone won a lot consecutively people immediately thought that person was good at math, the funny part about it all is that usually the person who won was someone who didn't have good grades in school, but people didn't care about this important detail and kept insisting that the winner was good at math. comments.body: Been playing cards, heard some superstitions but actually never cross my mind that I should do this and do that for good or bad luck. I know that some gamblers are very superstitious, but I try to stir away from it because we do know that it won't affect the result of the next card that you will dealt with. And this superstitions can be sum up to being a "Gamblers Fallacy".

comments.body: Quote from: bitzizzix on July 30, 2022, 02:48:50 PMTo be honest I've never come across or seen any of these things in real or online gambling, and those who use them because of myths, superstitions and legends have probably been around for a long time. And it may be believed from generation to generation that in fact it's all not necessarily the truth.In my opinion gambling is purely based on luck and skill, and there are also those who use it when luck is on the side of the person who uses it, they will consider it successful.and I don't really believe it because they are all beliefs that are not necessarily true, except outside of gambling.Like what I previously mentioned in a similar topic, these superstitious beliefs provide nothing against the odds. But, they in effect, provide something that gives the gambler the feeling of peace and comfort before they gamble. You can associate this like doing a pep-talk; it gives this certain boost of confidence and fearlessness to the gambler before he/she attempts to gamble on his own pace.Though this may be the case, people should not fully rely on these beliefs. But if these activities help them in reducing the stress, anxiety, and their doubt, then I see no reason for them to stop practicing such myths.
